repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Mining Development and
            Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's outcome is rated
            moderately satisfactory. Sustainability is rated unlikely on
            balance, though marginally so. Bank and borrower performance
            are both rated satisfactory, but quality at entry is rated
            unsatisfactory. The main lessons learned from this project
            are: Technical assistance that aims to encourage private
            investment in extractive industries requires the preparation
            of comprehensive EAs with a countrywide focus, with special
            attention given to reviewing the adequacy and sustainability
            of regulations and institutional mechanisms for protecting
            sensitive ecosystems and communities. The EA should be
            prepared as early as possible after project identification,
            its recommendations should be reflected in project design,
            and extensive consultations with all potential stakeholders
            are critical. Finally, appropriate mitigation rules and
            enforcement institutions should be developed as early as
            possible. When most environmental responsibilities are
            delegated to a sector ministry, as in Ecuador, it is
            important to reduce potential internal conflicts of interest
            between the sector ministry's roles as investment
            promoter and environmental control and enforcement agency,
            by clearly separating the responsibility for these
            functions. Furthermore, sector oversight capacity also needs
            to be built up within the Ministry of the Environment, and
            support of local communities needs to be secured. Projects
            and programs involving natural resources extraction need to
            be carefully and proactively managed. The participation of
            NGOs and potentially affected local community associations
            in the monitoring of impacts was effective in Ecuador. For
            technical assistance projects addressing complex
            environmental, social and regulatory issues, continued Bank
            involvement beyond project closure would enhance the
            likelihood of sustainability. In Ecuador, the abrupt cut-off
            of the Bank's and co financiers' support resulted
            in program discontinuity and lack of replication of project
            achievements, in particular in the ASM program. Programs
            aiming at reducing or eliminating negative impacts from
            artisan and informal small-scale mining require continuity
            over-time, flexible timing, and a comprehensive approach
            oriented toward addressing social, financial, and managerial
            aspects as well as legal and technical aspects.

Ecuador - Mining Development and
            Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project

Ecuador - Mining Development and

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Mining Development and
            Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Mining Development
            and Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project is
            rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as substantial, Bank
            performance as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as
            satisfactory. The key lessons drawn include: Sector
            development should be part of an overall political and
            economic reform. This project provides a good example of the
            importance to approach sector reform in an integrated way.
            It is critical to design and implement during project
            preparation and implementation a more systematic social
            strategy, including improved information and consultation
            participatory process. The geo-scientific information
            management represents a very valuable tool not only for
            sector development but also for land use and related
            potential conflicts management. The project has demonstrated
            the importance to use an integrated approach and to
            emphasize the socio-economic aspects related to the
            subsector situation to address artisanal and small-scale
            mining issues. The involvement and balance of foreign versus
            national expertise in project activities is an issue much
            debated with respect to technical assistance capacity
            building impact and sustainability. It is important for
            sectoral institutions and their staff to develop a strong
            commitment to reform and acquire a full sense of ownership
            and responsibility for the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Mining Development and
            Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project :
            Investigation Report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Investigation Report for the Mining
            Development and Environmental Control Technical Assistance
            Project in Ecuador examines the claims given by Requesters
            in regard to this project.  The Requesters claim that the
            communities they represent are likely to suffer material
            harm as a result of failures and omissions of the Bank in
            the design and implementation of the Project.  They claim
            that public release of maps with mineral data will attract
            mining companies and "informal" miners.  This
            would result in significant degradation of critical natural
            habitats. Management examined the claims and found that the
            Request was eligible for and Investigation. After examining
            the policies and procedures followed for the Project, the
            Investigation Report finds that the Bank was in compliance
            with numerous policies and procedures, but was inefficient
            in following environmental assessment procedures.

display_title.display_title:
Ecuador - Mining Development and
            Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project :
            Investigation Report : Management Response and Recommendation

1121314.subsc: Mining and other extractive,Central government administration

repnme.cdata!:
Ecuador - Mining Development and
            Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project :
            Management Response to Investigation Report

abstracts.cdata!:
This report constitutes the management
            response to the Inspection Panel ' s investigation
            report upon the Ecuador Mining Development and Environment
            Control Technical Assistance Project. The management concurs
            with the assessments of the Inspection Panel of the actions
            of the bank and accepts the position that a more expanded
            and robust Environmental Assessment and consultation process
            should have been undertaken. The management is not proposing
            any remedial efforts with regard to the claims made by the
            Requesters and notes the Inspection Panel indication that
            material adverse effects to the Requestors may be considered
            as remote. Bank staff will continue to work to implement
            actions agreed on under the Project with the following
            precautions: a) the participation of Nongovernmental
            organizations in monitoring the use and application of the
            information generated under the Project; b) enforcement of
            the standard license agreements for the use of the
            information; and c) further publication of brochures, and
            workshops on the use of geo-information. The development of
            consultation mechanisms for mining activities in Ecuador has
            been initiated and is linked to that of other extractive
            industries. There will be continuing support for
            conservation and environmental management in Ecuador
            including the strengthening of environmental institutions.

docna.cdata!:
Ecuador - Mining Development and
            Environmental Control Technical Assistance Project :
            Management Response to Investigation Report
